Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The GA-VSC Herbaria Collaborative: Phase I of a Statewide Consortium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Georgia's flora is ranked seventh nationally in species richness. The herbaria at University of Georgia [GA] and Valdosta State University [VSC] comprise 324,500 plant specimens, representing 84% of collections housed in Georgia. This funding fosters a formal GA−VSC partnership to produce an on-line state Atlas linked to specimen images and data. VSC infrastructure will also be enhanced with additional storage and processing of valuable rare specimens. The project will initiate a state-wide herbarium consortium, providing a model for most effective data mobilization as other collections are incorporated into the system. The network will provide global access to these collections, ensuring their relevance.

This project will promote learning through employment of graduate and undergraduate students and an innovative GA--VSC graduate student exchange program. Educational activities include herbarium tours to view work in progress, a teacher workshop, and creation of a herbarium at a non-profit organization promoting trees in urban Atlanta. All activities will endorse under-represented groups via student support. The user-friendly, Web-based GA--VSC Atlas will provide global access to floristic data. The database of maps, images, and label information has many practical applications for society at large, such as recognizing endangered or poisonous species ranges and plant communities requiring management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project was to digitize specimens and associated data in the Valdosta State University Herbarium [VSC], a repository of museum specimens and data documenting biodiversity of the southeastern United States, with special emphasis on the Georgia coastal plain. Through digitization and subsequent dissemination on the internet, derived specimen images and their associated data become readily available with great potential to support and advance ecological and biodiversity research. High-resolution photographs of more than 70,000 specimens in VSC were produced, and label data from these specimens were transcribed into a database. VSC images and data are being provided to the University of Georgia Herbarium [GA] for the on-line atlas of the Georgia flora under development there and are currently being served on-line as the Valdosta State University Virtual Herbarium, through a local cooperative effort between VSC and the university library, stimulated by this project and funded by Valdosta State University. VSC images and data are also being made publically available through web portals of iDigBio and the Consortium of North American Bryophyte Herbaria. 

Four papers derived from this project were published and three oral presentations – one involving a student, and five poster presentations, three involving students – were made at local, state and regional conferences. Student assistants presented their work at the 2013 Annual Meeting of the Georgia Academy of Science, the 2014 Annual Meeting of the Association of Southeastern Biologists [ASB], and the 2014 Valdosta State University Annual Undergraduate Research Symposium. One student assistant won the Southern Appalachian Botanical Society Student Poster Award for her presentation “Digitization of the Valdosta State University Herbarium: Undergraduate Student Perspectives” at the 2014 ASB Meeting. Protocols detailing routine herbarium activities as well as workflows for imaging specimens, processing of digital images, entering data from specimen labels were prepared and are publically available through the VSC web page and the iDigBio website.   

Digitization equipment purchased through this project will sustain on-going digitization efforts at VSC, making this valuable biodiversity resource widely available for research. Infrastructural improvements funded through this grant include 10 new herbarium cabinets and restoration of 51 old cabinets, insuring secure storage for valuable biodiversity specimens protecting them from possible insect and water damage. Funding also enabled processing of more than 9,300 backlog specimens, and more than 7,300 new archival geographically coded specimen folders were installed, reducing unnecessary handling of specimens and alleviating specimen damage. Backlog processing also generated more than 8,000 duplicate specimens exchanged with 15 other herbaria.

15 undergraduate student assistants employed through this project were taught about the importance of biological collections in biodiversity and ecological research and trained in museum and digitization techniques. Student assistants prepared and presented posters and talks at state and regional conferences, and one student was invited to present to a national audience at an iDigBio workshop. Preparation for these presentations emphasized the importance of review and revision, including multiple rounds of reviews and revisions – excellent preparation for graduate school and careers in science.
